SafetyInspectionBy: Office of Hazardous Materials Enforcement - DOT

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
CARGILL BARTOW

1.    Corporate Prevention and Emergency Response 
                                                                                                                                                                                     Cargill Fertilizer, LLC corporate environmental organization supports site prevention and emergency response programs with resources such as funding and training.  Each facility maintains emergency prevention and response procedures and equipment appropriate to the hazards onsite.  A team of employees trained to respond to specific hazards (the CERT) is maintained at this facility.  The CERT participates in biweekly training to ensure preparedness in the unlikely event of a hazardous chemical release.  

2. Description of Stationary Source

Anhydrous ammonia (ammonia) which is a regulated hazardous substance, is handled at the Bartow fertilizer manufacturing facility.   The hazardous properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe safety precautions in handling the substance to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to facility personnel health as well as contractors, and to reduce the threat to the community.  At the Bartow facility, ammonia is stored in greater than the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.  Ammonia is used as a raw material in the Cargill facility.  The ammonia is stored in tanks as a liquefied gas.  The ammonia is then piped to the monoammonium phosphate (MAP) and diammonium phosphate (DAP) plants.  Liquefied or gaseous ammonia may pose a health risk if the compressors, containers, or lines transferring the ammonia develop leaks or rupture.  Ammonia is brought into the facility  via the Tampa Bay Pipeline into four storage vessels (bullets). The capacity of each bullet is 200 tons.  Administrative controls at the facility limit the quantity of ammonia stored in each bullet to 175 tons.  

3. Prevention Program

Based on a review of the applicable regulations, Prevention

Program 3 requirements apply to this facility.  The main focus of the prevention program is to reduce the likelihood of a release by enforcing written safety and operating procedures, maintaining equipment, and training staff and contractors.   

4.    Accidental Releases

There have been no accidental releases in the past five years.

5.    Emergency Response Program

The current plan is coordinated with the Bartow Fire Department and they can be reached by dialing 911.
